HP i2000 (Itanium 1/Merced machine) adventures
description:
Hi y‚Äôall,

I lucked out on an HP i2000 recently. I‚Äôve been looking for one of these beasts for a few years now and one finally showed up, it‚Äôs effectively an Intel Itanium Software Development Vehicle/devkit rebadged by HP (and others) and sold as an Itanium workstation. They have the very rough Itanium first generation Merced chips.

This machine is pretty interesting, and a showcase of how rough and rushed (though simultaneously delayed) Itanium was - the firmware that it had when I got it was so broken that attempting to talk to the NIC under Linux would cause the machine to crash, and PXE from EFI was completely borked for example. Windows would refuse to boot, even.

I‚Äôve been on a bit of a journey to get the earliest IA-64 Windows builds up on the thing, but I haven‚Äôt had much luck outside of ‚ÄúWindows Advanced Server 1.2 Limited Edition‚Äù (same build # as Server 2K3, 3663, but the NT version wasn‚Äôt changed to 5.2 for some reason, so perhaps it was actually built earlier). You can see the full install process, making it a domain controller, etc. here: https://youtu.be/vemZXp_lUXY

I also got IA-64 Red Hat 7.2 going, slightly details of interest in the description here: https://youtu.be/qK5ub3H8md0

This model is also the only Itanium machine confirmed to be able to boot the only surviving result of Project Monterey, AIX for IA/64: https://youtu.be/MIsJ8TVJTKw which was finally dumped publicly a year or two ago. I also have a Compaq DL590/64, which shares Merced CPUs and I believe the chipset, but it won‚Äôt boot on there. Very picky.

I‚Äôm now trying my best to get even earlier Windows builds up, including 5.1.2462 (predates Advanced Server Limited Edition 1.0) and 5.1.3590 (ASLE 1.1), but have run into quite a bit of trouble. I‚Äôm very much not a Windows admin‚Ä¶

Both CDs boot to an error about not being able to read TXTSETUP.SIF (status 2); from what I can tell, TXTSETUP.SIF is responsible for telling the stage 1 of the Windows setup what directories to look for on the CD, which files need to be copied, etc. I futzed around with trying to correct this for a while, then decided to see if I could just net install instead. This opened up a whole other can of worms‚Ä¶ first of all, I couldn‚Äôt tell that PXE not working was because of the system firmware at first, but once I figured that out, I had to figure out Windows Deployment Services (WDS) and Remote Installation Services (RIS).

First I tried a Server 2003 R2 install server, but then after seeing it spit out 2462 and 3590 I learned that WDS in 2003 R2 is basically the Server 2008 version retrofitted into 2K3 R2. Eventually I landed on Server 2003 (non-R2) SP2, which has WDS but the legacy RIS is actually okay with 2462 and 3590. I was able to import 3590 okay, but 2462 had issues. When the system went to copy the files from the install media, I‚Äôd get a ‚ÄúThe system cannot find the file specified‚Äù error, and the error titlebar indicated it was looking under the root of the media for ‚Äòlang*‚Äô. Strange, because the lang folder would be under an architecture‚Äôs folder on the media (i386 and ia64). I didn‚Äôt think it would work, but I tried just copying the ia64\lang folder to the root, which got a lot further but then led me to an error about c2.bin/e100bnt5.sys. Tripredacus on MSFN suggested using procmon (Process Monitor) from SysInternals to trace what the RIS Setup was doing, which was a great help. Like I said, not a Windows person.

The last version of procmon.exe/SysInternals that seems to run on this era of Windows is 3.10. You need at least SP1 installed on Server 2K3 to use it. You can get it here: https://web.archive.org/web/20140625080651/http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/bb842062.aspx

I discovered the ‚Äúlang*‚Äù issue was from reminst.inf having an incorrect AdditionalClientDirs section. reminst.inf seems to be similar in function to txtsetup.sif, but for remote installs. The AdditionalClientDirs seems to tell RIS what other folders to grab installation files from. I changed it to:

[AdditionalClientDirs]
ia64\lang
ia64\asms
i386\asms

from just lang and asms. I guessed what to actually put based on the contents of reminst.inf from 3590. This got me back to the e100bnt5.sys error. I looked inside the media, and found no e100bnt5.sys, nor e100bnt5.sy_ (sy_ indicating a compressed Microsoft cabinet containing just e100bnt5.sys). Turns out, there‚Äôs a big cabinet called driver.cab under ia64, which contained a bunch of driver files (you guessed it!), but still no e100bnt5.sys. However, there was an e100w64.sys. My guess is that the driver got renamed during XP 64-bit/2K3 64-bit development, but not all of this build got the memo. I tried editing layout.inf (also plays a part in laying out the files needed to be copied for RIS installs, as far as I can tell) and txtsetup.inf to remove all references to e100bnt5.sys, but this didn‚Äôt help. I‚Äôm guessing the c2.bin file that shows in the RIS copy window at this error somehow has a hard dependency on e100bnt5.sys being there or something somehow, I took a quick look in a hex editor but didn‚Äôt find anything. I decided to just copy e100w64.sys to e100bnt5.sys in the driver cab, but this didn‚Äôt end up being straightforward either! Windows comes with makecab.exe, which will make cabinet files for you, but it has weird defaults such as only making floppy-ish sized cabs by default.

What I landed on:

Copying all of the contents of the original driver.cab to a path with no spaces (I used C:\DriverCab). Then:

copy C:\DriverCab\e100w64.sys to C:\DriverCab\e100bnt5.sys
dir C:\DriverCab /s /b /a-d > C:\Files.txt
makecab /D CabinetName1=driver.cab /D MaxDiskSize=163840000 /D DiskDirectoryTemplate=C:\ /F C:\Files.txt

(MaxDiskSize prevents the cab from being split into a bunch of small cabs; also thanks: https://superuser.com/a/1317492, https://ss64.com/nt/makecab.html)

Now I‚Äôm able to select it from the WDS OS selector, but after a ‚ÄúWaiting for reboot‚Ä¶‚Äù it just sits at a black screen, setup not starting. Darn. 3590 takes me to an error about an INF file in a temp folder being invalid‚Ä¶ more work to do. I‚Äôm thinking that maybe 2462 is just an incomplete/broken build though. If anyone has more knowledge or is interested and has ideas, please let me know! I hope somebody finds this interesting. :)

The AdditionalClientDirs seems to tell RIS what other folders to grab installation files from. I changed it to: 

```

ia64\lang
ia64\asms
i386\asms
```

from just `lang` and `asms`. I guessed what to actually put based on the contents of reminst.inf from 3590. This got me back to the e100bnt5.sys error. What I landed on:

